description: From Middle English tenement, from Anglo-Norman tenement (“holding”), from Old French tenement, from Medieval Latin tenimentum, from Latin teneō (“hold”).

entries.meaning: A building that is rented to multiple tenants, especially a low-rent, run-down one.
(law) Any form of property that is held by one person from another, rather than being owned.
examples: The island of Brecqhou is a tenement of Sark.
Where she came from no man could tell. There were some said she was no woman, but a ghost haunting some mortal tenement.
